conclusion: Understand the graph and the states
State A: Volume VA = V0, Temperature TA = T0, Pressure pA = p0
State B: Volume VB = 2V0, Temperature TB unknown, Pressure pB unknown
State C: Volume VC = V0, Temperature TC to be determined, Pressure pC unknown
Segment AB is parallel to the V-axis, meaning the volume is constant (V = V0) as the temperature increases from TA = T0 to TB
Since V is constant, the pressure must increase proportionally with temperature (p ∝ T)
Segment BC extension passes through the origin (O), indicating a direct proportionality between V and T (V ∝ T)
This implies that the pressure p remains constant along BC
Use the ideal gas law: pV = nRT
Relate State A using ideal gas law: pA VA = nRT_A, Substitute pA = p0, VA = V0, TA = T0: p0 V0 = nRT0
Relate State B using ideal gas law: pB VB = nRT_B, Substitute VB = 2V0: pB (2V0) = nRTB
Relate State C using proportionality: VC/T_C = VB/T_B, Substitute VC = V0, VB = 2V0, solve for TC: 1/T_C = 2/T_B, Invert the equation: TC = TB/2
Relate TB to T0: p ∝ T along AB, pB/pA = TB/TA, Substitute pA = p0, TA = T0, pB = 2p0: 2p0/p0 = TB/T0, Simplify: 2 = TB/T0, Solve for TB: TB = 2T0
Find TC: TC = TB/2, Substitute TB = 2T0: TC = 2T0/2
